A month later, my sleep regularity is at +90% in Sleep Cycle (where it has never been in the 7 years I've been using that app) and I'm sleeping better, snoring less, and have worked my sleep debt down to almost nothing. I particularly enjoy the phone shaking challenge in the morning. And I can tell this app is going to change my life.

title: Frustrating/fussy and negative
review:
On one hand I love the building aspect of this app-I've been using it about a month. On the other there are some fundamental design flaws that run for to good sleep hygiene; some of which would happen in any sleep promoting app and others which they could improve. 

It's never pleasant to wake up to "you have failed" if you oversleep.

The alarm does not adjust with any change you make to your target wake up time. 

The alarm itself is wonky, and doesn't always go off. 

The controls are fussy and there are far too many rules to do the simple task the app is supposed to do. 

You have to remember to push "sleep" every night before you go to sleep. I don't see a way around this but it's one more thing to think of when you're in bed. 

Finally, some creative mind will have to come up with an app that doesn't compel you to be on your phone. Screens are a big part of the reason many of us have bad sleep habits! Plus, it would be nice not to have to be on your phone when you wake up, too. As it stands you have to unlock your phone, go into the app, and activate it (and then collect your coins, so you're immediately playing a game right when you wake up). 

In short, too much fuss for a simple goal without a lot of incentive.

title: Great app - needs some improvements
review:
I started using this app two weeks ago and it has really motivated me to try to keep a regular sleep schedule. I get so excited about seeing the new buildings the next morning and it motivates me to stay on track for the longer term incentives and more rare buildings. It‚Äôs exactly the kind of low stakes, positive incentive that feels motivating without building more pressure that is counter productive for sleeping. There are two ways this app could be improved:

1) I would LOVE if there was a setting that would allow you to leave the app for 5 min (or a limited time) without destroying your buildings. I often wake up in the middle of the night and use a meditation app to get back to sleep. If there was a way to leave the app for 5 min every hour or something without destroying the building that would allow me to turn on the meditation and return to the app. When I‚Äôve turned off strict mode altogether to use any app on my phone during sleep, I inevitably abuse it and am on my phone for hours. (I have ADD and it‚Äôs just too tempting!)

1) the design your own town feature has some bugs and is hard to use. I often get an error that my town is out of sync and I need to reload, and when I do I am no longer able to continue making some edits - like returning recently purchased items without losing my coins. The items will only face one or two directions, so it is hard to tell from the store if they will work for the place im hoping to use them for. I would love if they improved this or made it so that you can delete an item at any time and get your coins refunded.

title: Not ideal for third shifters
review: This app is unfortunately not for people like me. I‚Äôm a longtime user of the Forest app which has always been one of my favorites for when it comes to forcing myself to get things done, whether that‚Äôs studying or reading or napping without interruptions from my phone. Yes, I have used Forest for sleep in the past, which is why I thought this app would be a good one for me. Putting my phone away and getting to sleep has occasionally been an issue for me as I have a crazy third shift sleep pattern that causes me insomnia, as well as a very restless mind. I‚Äôm always going to sleep too late and waking up too early. When I wake up too early, I tend to play on my phone to ‚Äútire myself out,‚Äù but of course that only serves to wake me up even more. So I thought this application really does have the potential to be the answer to that. It has all the same motivational factors as Forest with build progress that I‚Äôm loathe to interrupt by using my phone in the middle of the night. It has a design that does not encourage you to wake up too early. Unless I‚Äôm understanding incorrectly, you pick your preferred bed time and wake time for the week (you can give yourself two days off, such as the weekend) and you must attempt to consistently go to sleep and also wake up within two hours of either goal. Cool, but I quickly found out that this functionality has its major drawbacks for a person with a fluid work schedule. Anyway, it‚Äôs easy to understand that an app like this is intended for the average person who is up during the day and sleeps during the night with a fairly regular routine who just needs some help promoting their sleep hygiene. I, on the other hand, work third shift, three random days a week, and my schedule is not set at all. So I am constantly having to change the sleep and wake goals, which resets my streak and is overall just a general pain to do on a nightly basis. I think the concept of the app is very good though, if I still had that kind of schedule. I‚Äôll admit that when I downloaded it, I was really just hoping for another version of Forest that was town-themed and specifically made for naps. I thought it would have a more whimsical and spontaneous option exactly like Forest‚Äôs format where you could decide on a whim that you wanted to build a house for a little catnap, pick the design, then go. Something you could use anytime you wanted. Not something that has to be so structured for people who do not have a structured schedule. But like I said, there is already an app for that, and it‚Äôs called Forest, so I may just go back to using Forest and setting my tree tags to ‚Äúsleep.‚Äù But because I think this app is quite good with just some room for more flexible features, I believe it deserves 4 stars! I‚Äôm not sure how much I‚Äôll use it just because of the inconvenience of the weekly format it encourages. This app is not for people like me, so I probably should not have purchased it.

title: Beautiful and Functional
review:
Gameplay

Although it's not listed as such, sleep town is a game. Every night you go to bed on time and wake up on time you're given a reward. While this app isn't the first to do this it's definitely the best I've seen, I go to bed every night on time so I can see what beautiful building I'm going to wake up to in the morning. I find myself estatic rising in the morning and seeing what type of building I've created. This app once made my day because I awoke to the sight of a completed fairground. Not to mention in the new 2.0 version I'm absolutely compelled to get up on time so I can have a few minutes to spend my coins and edit my town. The ability to create my own town let's me live out my dreams of city planning. The addition of achievements I think was an amazing way to introduce new decorations. I hope to see more in the future.

My only gripe with Sleep Town's current system is that each block is created by a 3x3 grid with (most) housing and decorations taking up 1 square. I think a block should be a 9x9 area and while (most) housing should take up a 3x3 chunk, decorations should take a 1x1 area all the way to a 3x3 with additional opportunities for more complex shapes such as a fountain stretching 3x9. It would also be nice to be able to turn buildings (they look a little goofy all bunched up facing the same direction.) but I can respect that would require completely redrawing all the artistic assets from another angle. Which brings me to the next section.

Artwork

This app has some of the best artwork I've ever seen. Now admittedly I'm a little biased on this point, the artwork has a sort of minimalist feel to it that I have found I love. Seeing the beautiful and often complex architecture and design of the buildings has filled me with such immense satisfaction that if this app was simply a way for me to view this artwork for 99 cents I would have still bought it. By combining simple geometric shapes and familiar ideas of constructions I find myself drawn to admiring what would appear to be a rather mediocre medium income house. Then occasionaly I'll stumble upon a house I'd  assume to be owned by a millionaire and gawk mindlessly for a solid 60 seconds. 

U.I.

Sleep Town's user interface leaves a little lacking. While I do like the simple five buttons at the top of screen I feel like the settings are a huge mess. It needs a rehaul desperately. Perhaps a more spaced out section with subcategories that drop down so it doesn't look so cluttered?

Conclusion

Overall I think Sleep Town is a fantastic way to burn a dollar. I think it'd currently underrated and deserves a lot more attention than what it currently has. I hope to see it become more frequently used in the future and look forward to further updates. I can't currently give a 4.5 so I figure why not round up?

title: Finally! Healthy Sleeping Habits
review: I'm sold.  This really works.  I've been using the app for 21 days straight. I've gone to bed on time, and gotten 8 hours of sleep for 3 straight weeks!  I know this sounds like an exaggeration, but this is life changing for me.  I've had the bad habit, for years, of staying up late working.  I would press snooze on the built in bedtime alarm on iOS.  The fact that I would break my building streak has kept me going.  I'm waking up early and getting work done, with clear head and a cup of coffee.  Having to shake your phone vigorously guarantees that you wake up.    Much thanks to the developer.

title: Lovely app
review:
This is a really nice app. It looks beautiful and the interface is simple. It helps give you a reason to put your phone down and go to sleep when you need to.

My only gripe is that you lose all your progress with consecutive days if you redo your sleep and wake up times. If you have a consistent schedule I can see it being really nice, but when I'm switching from day shifts to night shifts I have to adjust my sleep and wake up times and I find it works best for me to do a small change each day. For me, it would be more useful if the consecutive days was based on how many days I slept for a goal number of hours. Perhaps some way to switch whether your goal is to go to bed at a consistent time or to get a certain amount of sleep? I still really enjoy this app and will keep using it, I just wish that my progress wouldn't restart because of a schedule change!

title: Good sleep app
review:
I had previously been using forest to enforce my bedtime, so when I saw that the developer had released an app explicitly for that purpose, I was thrilled. Overall, I am quite happy, however there are a couple of shortcomings that the developer needs to address to take this app from "good" to "great"

First, the bedtime notification is  not persistent enough. Users should be able to set the app to remind them more than once before bedtime. Two nights in the first week I used Sleep Town, I dismissed the 15 minute notification so I could finish up work, the got distracted and didn't open the app in time.

This brings me to my second point: it would be nice if there were a way to still use the app to enforce sleep even if you've missed bedtime. Perhaps one could plant trees/hedges that don't produce revenue, but still prettify the city? I could just use forest for this, but it's nice to have an all-in one app (and forest doesn't let me have those longer times).

In addition to these main problems, I also have some minor UI quibbles (I wish you could view the city in portrait mode), but other than that, this is a very good app, and would definitely get five stars if the issues discussed above were fixed.

title: Much needed
review: I am a major culprit of using my phone before bed which keeps me up later than I intend on being- this is a good concept and I loved your other app Forest that I just had to get this one. Simple- not to mention the shake in the morning is a good way to wake someone up!

title: Define: Shake
review:
What a lousy user experience. First morning waking up with the app. I was all excited to complete my building, but no matter what I did, I couldn't gain any progress on the shake meter. So my building failed.

Developers, before you respond to me with information about changing the shake difficulty level, you need to realize that doesn't matter. The word shake is pretty clear, but you somehow built an app that didn't know what shaking means. Because when I tested the "easy" level after my building failed, I saw that no shaking was required.

The truth is, you failed me in your design, which created a poor first experience with the app. I'm no longer interested and will be asking for a refund.

title: App Suggestion
review:
Quickie Review:
I gave this app 3 stars because it is a good idea that has allot of room to grow. It is a bedtime helper (helps you put down the phone) that uses incentives to help you achieve your sleep goal. For this reason, the app works and is useful.

Constructive Crictism:
Personally, my life has a crazy schedule. My job does not allow me to have a consistent sleep schedule as in midnight to 8a every day. I would be very nice if the developers could allow you to change the time on the fly with penalizing you. Suppose allow for a duration in the day where changes are allowed. In addition, the developers could add some sort of week schedule that we could program each week. Both would be nice. 

There are some smoothness issues but for bow the above implementation would be much appreciated.

title: Nagging
review:
App has potential to motivate user to go to bed and get up on time, but has some major problems. 

1. Constant nag screens demanding user sign up on for web account. Sorry no. For people who might be willing to set up a web account there needs to be some explanation of the benefits. If the developer insists on retaining these nag screens, they should be used much more sparingly.  

2. Developer chose to force users to turn their devices to predetermined orientation for each view rather than allow user to choose orientation. Being forced to turn one's device repeatedly while using an app grates. It is a good example of why most apps don't manage orientation this way. 

3. While it's possible to change sleep and wake up times, it should be possible to do this without penalty. There are a number of reasons a user may need to change times. For starters traveling to a different time zone.

title: Solid idea, more game would make it better
review: My husband and I have been using the app for a little over a week and we love the idea. It's fun to see which buildings we get. But the app needs a little more gaming to make it a useful long term tool--for example, customizable buildings, a map you can move the housings around on, villagers to please, etc. Adding more features will make this game really fun to use in the long run.

title: It works but needs improvement
review: Recently the ambient sound doesn't work and there are no other sound options. Also once you oversleep it provides a "failure" button which is great because it can log how much you overslept but there is no button for going to sleep late. I also wish it would keep the logged sleep data even if the building is demolished.

title: Doesn't work properly
review:
I kept trying to input a specific time of going to sleep at 12am (I have been sleeping later because of school work) and it couldn't understand that and kept changing the time to 12pm. When i switched the time to 11:55pm it thought i meant 11:55am and then my wake up time of 5:30am switched to 5:30pm and didn't want to change back. 

Please fix this. I love your other app, forest, because it helps me a lot. 

Also it would be nice to add different times for each night before you go to sleep. Or at least allow us to make a weekly schedule (that is easily adjustable, not going into the settings and other menus to switch it).
Thank you for reading all of this. Hope to see an improvement. I see a lot of potential in this app. This could be better than apple's free app, but at the time being it isn't.

title: I love this app!
review:
I am already a die-hard user of this developer's Forest productivity app...and SleepTown is equally great! As someone who has trouble trading distractions for a good night's rest, this app has proven very useful. I usually avoid destroying a structure at all costs, even when I'm having trouble sleeping and the temptation of my phone is particularly strong. Ultimately, the motivation that this app provides helps me fall asleep faster and wake up more refreshed.

WORD OF ADVICE TO NEW USERS: before going to sleep with this app on the first night, be sure to set the shake setting to "easy." You must shake VERY vigorously on the harder settings, which causes frequent failure and destroyed buildings. I'm not very strong, but I've never had trouble with the easy setting.

One suggestion for the developer might be to introduce more things to spend coins on. I don't want to bulldoze my destroyed buildings, since they are a record of nights that I didn't sleep as well...but as far as I can tell, bulldozing is the only option for spending the coins we collect. Maybe options to purchase relaxing sleep sounds or new bedtime/wake-up alarm sounds (kind of like the sounds available for "purchase" in Forest)? Or options to use coins to donate to charity (as in Forest)...or purchase new types of buildings or building features (also in Forest...can you tell I like Forest?). This app is new, and new features show up in Forest all the time, so I'm sure something is in the works... In any case, keep up the great work! Your apps have improved my quality of life in more ways than one!
